stem-table.stem: Consonants, Dipthongs, ι, ω STEMS IN ι and υ π-MUTE/κ-MUTE or LABIAL/PALATAL (no neuter) STEMS IN DIPTHONG (ευ,αυ,ου) (no neuter) ω-STEM (no feminine or neuter) (οι) (no masculine or neuter) τ-MUTE or DENTAL (τ,δ,θ,ατ) LIQUID, NASAL (incl. SYNCOPATED LIQUID)(λ,ρ) (ν) (ερ >> ρ) (no neuter) STEMS IN σ (εσ,ας,ος) (no masculine)

On stem ending in ν, ν doubled in gen. Sing Aeolic (e.g. μῆνς, μῆννος...)
Also in inscriptions and expressions of swearing
(Borrowed from 1st decl) Sometimes in proper names whose nominative ends in -ης
From -ας-stems (properly αι)
(ε)υς instead of (ε)ος or ους (gen) for (3rd decl) words whose nominative ends in -ος
In 3rd decl. Only in the words αἰδώς (Attic) and ἠώς (Homer and Ionic)
Contraction of a stem in οι and an ι-ending
Stronger form of Ionic contractions of οι-stems (in the nominative)

Nominative plural contraction of -ειδ+ες after dropping the δ (Used for accusative too)
Plurals & duals occur rarely (and w/ 2nd decl endings) for 3rd decl οι-stem nouns

(Homer) for Attic (ῳτ)ι

Also an irregular ending for other stem(s)
In inscriptions
Plural endings for otherwise dual noun, οσσε (eyes)
